citations.narrative:
The licensee is not ensuring that animals are housed in the same pen with animals that don’t cause them pain or
discomfort. In the finisher barn, a pig with a recent rectal prolapse had been separated from its pen-mates and placed in a
pen with five other pigs who had been isolated for lameness. Per the licensee, he had been planning to treat the prolapse
later in the day. Per the attending veterinarian (AV), the AV had previously pre-approved the rectal prolapse treatment
protocol, but had not discussed whether or not pigs with rectal prolapses should be separated from other pigs.
Upon entering the barn, the inspector observed bright red blood on two pigs and on the pen floor. This blood was from the
pen-mates biting the rectal prolapse, which was bright red and edematous. The pig with the prolapse had blood covering
its rump and both back legs.
Having pen-mates bite on a recent rectal prolapse may cause pain or distress to the animal. Animals housed in the same
primary enclosure must be compatible. Animals shall not be housed near animals that interfere with their health or cause
them discomfort.
Correct by November 25, 2024. The licensee corrected the noncompliance at the time of the inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensees.
n

narrative:
3.133  Direct
   
Separation. 
The licensee is not ensuring that animals are housed in the same pen with animals that don’t cause them pain or 
discomfort. In the finisher barn, a pig with a recent rectal prolapse had been separated from its pen-mates and placed in a 
pen with five other pigs who had been isolated for lameness. Per the licensee, he had been planning to treat the prolapse 
later in the day. Per the attending veterinarian (AV), the AV had previously pre-approved the rectal prolapse treatment 
protocol, but had not discussed whether or not pigs with rectal prolapses should be separated from other pigs.  
 
Upon entering the barn, the inspector observed bright red blood on two pigs and on the pen floor. This blood was from the 
pen-mates biting the rectal prolapse, which was bright red and edematous. The pig with the prolapse had blood covering 
its rump and both back legs.  
 
Having pen-mates bite on a recent rectal prolapse may cause pain or distress to the animal. Animals housed in the same 
primary enclosure must be compatible. Animals shall not be housed near animals that interfere with their health or cause 
them discomfort.  
 
Correct by November 25, 2024. The licensee corrected the noncompliance at the time of the inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensees. 
 
 n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
